passages.text: The Daily Canuck 29.08.2025

With Canadian bank earnings season almost at a close (LB reports this morning), relative to expectations, it was a positive quarter, with most exceeding expectations and all reasonably cautiously optimistic on the outlook. While challenges are likely to persist, it appears that sentiment has shifted more positive towards the banks as a result of the solid third quarter.

Following EQB's Q3 miss, we are reducing our rating to Hold from Buy. Out of necessity, EQB is undergoing a major re- haul of its executive talent at a point where it is facing significant operational headwinds. While its business model is far from broken, we do not expect to see any immediate solutions to the pressures it currently faces. As such, we believe that its valuation will be compressed until the rough patch eases, and we recommend sitting on the sidelines. For our report, see "EQB 3Q25 Earnings Review: Credit Headwinds Continue - Downgrade to Hold". With CM and TD closing out the 'Big 6' Q3 earnings with beats, below are our key thoughts coming out of the quarter: For CIBC, we believe the bank reported exceptionally strong earnings as it did not receive the same tailwind from lower provisions as peers. Further, the bank did not call out non- recurring securities losses as non- core, further bolstering the quality of earnings. Key to sustaining and expanding its valuation multiple will be maintaining the success that it has achieved in its net interest margins, which we believe the bank will be successful at. For our report, see "CM 3Q25 Earnings Review: Strong Finish as the CEO Rides into the Sunset". For TD, although the bank's third quarter is arguably not as impressive as some of its peers, we believe that it is demonstrating solid progress in improving the profitability of its U.S. segment. Further, we are confident that the management team will provide compelling arguments for profitability improvements at its strategic update next month. While TD has enjoyed a strong year- to- date run, we believe that additional upside is still available. For our report, see "TD 3Q25 Earnings Review: Steady Progress Rewards Bottom Line". Closing out the banks Q3 reporting season this morning is LB, with consensus forecasting EPS of \(\) 0.72\$ On the macro front, for this morning, Statistics Canada will release June and Q2 GDP data. Looking ahead, next week, a relatively quiet one for economic releases, with manufacturing PMI due out after Labour Day on Tues, while trade balance data is scheduled for release on Thurs. Jeffers Global Bank Valuation Comps - 26/08/2025 Jeffers Global Brokers, AMs & Exchanges Valuation Comps - 30/06/2025

Canada Records a Bump in Job Vacancies (BBG- BNN) The latest data from Statistics Canada indicates a bump in job vacancies to 492,000, partially offsetting the cumulative decline recorded in May and April. Year- over- year, job vacancies declined by 59,200 (- 10.7%) in June. Meanwhile, average weekly earnings were up 3.7% to \(\) 1,302\(in June Y / Y,\) and follows a 3.3% increase in May. Month- over- month, average weekly earnings were up 0.7% in June.
Guardian Capital Agrees To Be Taken Private by Desjardins Group in \(\) 1.67\$ Billion Deal (CP) Consolidation in Canada's financial sector continues, as Desjardins Group is acquiring Guardian
Figure 1 - EQB - Reported Net Interest Margins
Source: Company reports, Jefferies

Capital Group Ltd for \(\) 1.67\(billion or\) \ \(68\) per share, the co - operative financial group said on Thursday. Guardian will be taken private, and the deal, subject to approvals, is expected to close in the first quarter of 2026. Desjardins says the deal will bring together the strengths of Desjardins Global Asset Management, and Guardian to form an organization with \(\) 280\$ billion in assets.

Canada Records a Bump in Job Vacancies (BBGN) Yesterday, Bloomberg- BNN reported that the latest data from Statistics Canada indicates a bump in job vacancies to 492,000, partially offsetting the cumulative decline recorded in May and April. Year- over- year, job vacancies declined by 59,200 (- 10.7%) in June. Meanwhile, average weekly earnings were up 3.7% to \(1,302 in June Y/Y,\) and follows a 3.3% increase in May. Month- over- month, average weekly earnings were up 0.7% in June. Construction was the only sector to record a significant monthly change in the number of job vacancies, which increased by 4,600 (+13.1%) to 39,500, partially offsetting the decline in May (- 5,400 or - 13.4%). The job vacancy rate in construction was 3.2% in June, up from 2.9% in May but down 0.4 percentage points from June 2024 (3.6%).

Guardian Capital Agrees To Be Taken Private by Desjardins Group in \(\) 1.67\(Billion Deal (CP) Yesterday, the Canadian Press reported that consolidation in Canada's financial sector continues, as Desjardins Group is acquiring Guardian Capital Group Ltd for\) \ \(1.67\) billion or \(\) 68\(per share, the cooperative financial group said on Thursday. Guardian will be taken private, and the deal, subject to approvals, is expected to close in the first quarter of 2026. Desjardins says the deal will bring together the strengths of Desjardins Global Asset Management, and Guardian to form an organization with\) \ \(280\) billion in assets. Desjardins said this deal builds on a series of strategic moves to expand its growth in the Canadian financial landscape. "By combining our strengths with Guardian, we are building a leading platform with the scale, capabilities, and reach to serve investors in Canada and around the world," said Desjardins Group president and chief executive Guy Cormier, in a statement.

In EQB's third quarter, although the pressures were different, the bank's Q3 miss mirrors its disappointing results from the second quarter. Provisions for credit loses remain a headwind, but although commercial stabilized, it was its personal lending portfolio that exhibited weakness in the quarter. Further, while loan volumes remained strong, net interest margins were negatively impacted by lower rates on loans, while funding costs remained much stickier.

We view the current pressure on growth and profitability as largely transitory as EQB's business model and platform remains a compelling proposition. However, the dual headwinds of a challenging macro environment as well as a significant transition in its management team implies that rectifying the several issues impacting EQB in the quarter may take some time.

It appears that EQB is continuing to sacrifice its net interest margins via maintaining high interest savings rates to attract core customers at the cost of near term net interest margins. While we believe that this is likely a winning strategy over the longer term, the immediate impact on profitability in context of heightened credit costs is jarring. Further, post the unexpected passing of its former CEO, EQB is dealing with new (and not so new) members on its executive committee.

Coming out of the quarter, we are reducing our rating to a Hold, commensurate with the \(\) 12\(reduction in our target price to\) \ \(107\) . That said, should we see a resumption of growth and profitability early in 2026, it would not be beneath us to reconsider our rating once again as we have faith in the platform and management, once it is able to stabilize the business.
For our report, see "EQB 3Q25 Earnings Review: Credit Headwinds Continue - Downgrade to Hold".

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) is \(20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus \(20\%\) or less within a 12- month period. NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company.
NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations.
Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies methodology for assigig ratings may include the fllowing: market capitalization, maturity, growth/val, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a 15% stop loss, and the remainder will have a 20% stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
